intro: Anil campestris, commonly known as field pennycress, is an annual herbaceous plant native to Europe, Asia, and North Africa. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae, which includes many other economically important plants such as mustard and cabbage. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with pinnately compound leaves and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its seeds are enclosed in a capsule and are often used in traditional medicine and as a source of oil. Anil campestris is also known for its ability to thrive in disturbed soils and is sometimes considered a weed in agricultural settings.
